kihkch2xText:
Cognitive symptoms are common in MDD, may
persist despite treatment response or remission,
increasing the risk of relapse1-4
kihkch2yText: Disease STAR*DTreatment Goals Adverse events Anhedonia Emotional bluntingCognitive Symptoms in AsiaCognitive Symptoms
Brintellix_50d763643: During the acute phase, cognitive symptoms are common in patients with MDD*5
Brintellix_5a332d3f5: In a 3-year prospective study of 267 initially depressed primary care patients we established per week the presence/absence of the individual DSM-IV depressive symptoms during subsequent major depressive episodes (MDEs) and episodes of (partial) remission. This was accomplished by means of 12 assessments at 3-monthly intervals with the Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI).
Brintellix_551400cd9: 94%
Brintellix_572e38cd0:
In one study, cognitive
problems dominated and
were present for up to
94% of the time during
depressive episodes1
(n=267)
Brintellix_54771601f: Even when patients responded to treatment, cognitive symptoms may continue to be highly prevalent and persistent*2,5
Brintellix_5b99eff70: This report describes the residual symptom domains and individual depressive symptoms in a large representative sample of outpatients with nonpsychotic MDD who responded without remitting after up to 12 weeks of citalopram treatment in the Sequenced Treatment Alternatives to Relieve Depression (STAR*D) study. Response was defined as 50% or greater reduction in baseline 16-item Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology–Self-report (QIDS-SR16) by treatment exit, and remission as a final QIDS-SR16 of less than 6.
Brintellix_5b1f5eb6f: 70%
Brintellix_5471f0610:
Another study showed
that 70% of patients
who responded to
treatments still had
cognitive symptoms2
(n=428)
Brintellix_531bcc500: Even during periods of remission, cognitive symptoms may continue to be highly prevalent and persistent*2,5
Brintellix_5a57004bb: In a 3-year prospective study of 267 initially depressed primary care patients we established per week the presence/absence of the individual DSM-IV depressive symptoms during subsequent major depressive episodes (MDEs) and episodes of (partial) remission. This was accomplished by means of 12 assessments at 3-monthly intervals with the Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI).
Brintellix_5c2d1d069: 44%
Brintellix_5d348b428:
Even in patients thought to
be in remission, cognitive
symptoms were shown to
be present in depressed
patients for an average
of 44% of the time during
periods of remission1
(n=267)
Brintellix_53c351545:
Residual cognitive and mood symptoms are predictors of relapse*4
Patients with residual symptoms of depression are 3 times more likely to relapse6
Brintellix_52cc6740b:
Residual symptoms defined as HAM-D17 total score ≥8. Relapse occurred in 13/17 patients with residual symptoms compared to 10/40 without residual symptoms (p<0.001). Remission was defined as 2 consecutive months, retrospectively rated, below the RDC for primary unipolar major depression.
Relapse was defined as a return to satisfy RDC definite major depression for ≥1 month.
Brintellix_58607f2b2: Proportion relapsing
Brintellix_5d791ddca: Months between remission and relapse, or end of study
Brintellix_57efb5617:
Increases risk of relapse
Patients exhibiting residual cognitive symptoms have been shown to be at increased risk of relapse1
Brintellix_50bae5107:
Associated with poor patient functioning
Cognitive symptoms are associated with impairments in patient functioning and decreased health-related quality of life1,2
Brintellix_5a3135fb0:
Predictor of poor long-term functioning
The severity of cognitive symptoms has also been reported to be an independent and significant predictor of later functional impairment3,4
